questions.text: In a rural health center in Uttar Pradesh, India, a 5-year-old child presents with a two-day history of sore throat and low-grade fever. The healthcare provider notes a grayish-white membrane covering the child's tonsils and pharynx, accompanied by significant cervical lymphadenopathy. The child has received only one dose of the diphtheria vaccine due to limited healthcare access. Diphtheria is suspected. To confirm the diagnosis, a throat swab is taken. Which special staining technique should be used to identify the diphtheria bacillus in a laboratory setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

Ponder’s stain, Neisser stain and Albert stain are the special stains used for diphtheria.

 

These stains helps to identify the characteristic club-shaped morphology of the bacteria- Corynebacterium diphtheriae and the presence of metachromatic granules within the cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Ponder’s stain - Ponder's stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules formed in the polar regions

 

Option B: Neisser stain - A microbiological stain for visualising the polar bodies in the cytoplasm of gram-positive bacteria. This staining is used to identify diphtheria bacteria. Cells are stained with methylene blue and crystal violet in acidic solution and then counterstained with chrysoidin solution.

 

Option C: Albert’s stain - A kind of differential stain used for staining and identifying metachromatic granules. The granules appear purple-black when exposed to Albert's stain and against the light green cytoplasm. Albert stain only acts to stain metachromatic granules and no other granules in the bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of a sore throat, low-grade fever, and a grayish-whitemembrane covering the tonsils and throat, that bleeds on peeling- called as pseudomembranealong with enlarged cervical lymph nodes giving a characteristic Bull’s neck appearance are all consistent with diphtheria.
  • Ponder’s stain, Neisser stain and Albert stain are the special stains used for diphtheria.
  • Treatment of diphtheria involves the administration of diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics- Penicillin/Erythromycin. It is also important to isolate the infected individual to prevent the spread of the disease to others.
  • Diphtheria is a serious and potentially life-threatening bacterial infection that requires immediate medical attention.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1345-1348.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child in a rural healthcare clinic near Pune, India, presents with a persistent cough that has lasted for 3 weeks. The child, who has a history of missing several scheduled vaccinations due to accessibility issues, also exhibits a fever of 38.5°C and difficulty breathing. The mother reports that the cough is worse at night and the child has had intermittent episodes of wheezing. On examination, crackles are heard upon auscultation in the right upper lobe, and decreased breath sounds are noted. A chest X-ray has been performed, showing an area of infiltration in the right upper lobe, as shown below. Based on the clinical findings and imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary tuberculosis

 

Option C:

 

The most likely diagnosis in this case is pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

The presence of a persistent cough for 3 weeks, fever, difficulty in breathing, and crackles heard on auscultation of the chest, along with infiltration in the right upper lobe on chest X-ray are all consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Bronchial asthma, typically presents with wheezing, shortness of breath, and chest tightness.

 

Option B: Pneumonia, presents with cough, fever, and chest pain, but the chest X-ray findings are typically different from that of tuberculosis. Also, inpneumonia, there won’t be persistent cough for 3 weeks.

 

Option D: Congenital heart disease, presents with cyanosis, poor feeding, and failure to thrive, but not with persistent cough and infiltrates on chest X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

Persistent cough, fever, and signs of respiratory distress, along with a history of incomplete vaccination and specific radiographic findings of  infiltration of right upper lobe, in a high TB-prevalence area, pulmonary tuberculosis is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1445-1460.

questions.text: Match the peripheral smear findings and its associated conditions in column A and B:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A3 B4 C2 D1

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Macro-ovalocytes and Howell-Jolly bodies are typically found in conditions where there is abnormal red blood cell maturation or after splenectomy, which is often seen in megaloblastic anemia due to folate or vitamin B12 deficiency.

Option B: Heinz bodies and bite cells are a classic finding in G6PD deficiency, as oxidative stress causes denaturation of hemoglobin, which precipitates within the cell, and portions of these cells are bitten off (particularly by the spleen), leading to 'bite cells'.

Option C: Target cells are commonly seen in a number of conditions including thalassemia and liver disease. They are named for the bullseye appearance created by an excess of red blood cell membrane.

Option D: Spherocytes are most commonly associated with hereditary spherocytosis but can also be present in autoimmune hemolyticanemia (AIHA), where antibodies against red blood cells cause them to assume a sphere shape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition page page 10,036

choices.text: The child is at risk of developing gallstones
Iron supplements are indicated in the management of the disease
The child may require blood transfusions

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-year-old child to a local clinic with concerns about the child's noticeably distended abdomen and a history of recurrent infections. Upon physical examination, the child exhibits notable pallor and splenomegaly. The physical examination findings of the child revealed the following image. Additionally, an X-ray of the skull shows abnormal bone structure with a "crew cut" appearance, indicative of bone marrow expansion. A peripheral blood smear reveals microcytic hypochromic red blood cells and target cells. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iron supplements are indicated in the management of the disease.

 

Option C:

 

Iron supplements may actually exacerbate the symptoms of beta-thalassemia as patients with the disease are at risk for iron overload.

 

Beta-thalassemia is a genetic disorder that affects the production of beta-globin chains and is characterized by microcytic hypochromic RBCs and target cells. Patients with the disease may require blood transfusions and are at risk for complications such as splenomegaly, recurrent infections, and gallstones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The child may have beta-thalassemia: True, the clinical findings of facial bone deformities, splenomegaly, and a blood smear showing microcytic hypochromic RBCs with target cells are consistent with beta-thalassemia.

 

Option B. The child is at risk of developing gallstones: True, chronic hemolysis associated with beta-thalassemia increases the risk of bilirubinate gallstones.

 

Option D. The child may require blood transfusions: True, patients with beta-thalassemia major often require regular blood transfusions to manage severe anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-thalassemia can present with facial bone deformities, splenomegaly, and specific blood smear findings. Management often involves regular blood transfusions, while iron supplementation is not typically indicated due to the risk of iron overload.

 

Ref; OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 339-342

choices.text: The child may require a splenectomy.
The condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern
Spectrin mutation can lead to this condition
The peripheral smear may reveal target cells

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with a known family history of hereditary spherocytosis is brought to the clinic by his mother. The child presents with clinical signs of pallor and jaundice. Laboratory evaluation including a peripheral smear demonstrates the presence of spherocytes and a notably increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC). Given the family history and clinical presentation, which of the following statements is incorrect in relation to the child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The peripheral smear may reveal target cells

 

Option D:

 

Target cells are typically not associated with hereditary spherocytosis; instead, they are more commonly seen in conditions such as thalassemia or liver disease. Hereditary spherocytosis is characterized by the presence of spherocytes on the blood smear and an increased MCHC.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The child may require a splenectomy: True, splenectomy is a treatment option for hereditary spherocytosis to decrease hemolysis.

 

Option B. The condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern: True, although it can also be inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Option C. Spectrin mutation can lead to this condition: True, spectrin mutations are a common cause of hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hereditary spherocytosis, often characterized by spherocytes on the peripheral smear and increased MCHC, is commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and may involve spectrin mutations. Splenectomy can be part of the management; however, target cells are not a feature of this condition and their presence would suggest an alternative or additional diagnosis.

 

Ref; OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 337

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his yellow-tinted skin and a visibly enlarged abdomen. On physical examination, the physician notes excessive pallor and an enlarged spleen. The peripheral smear reveals the following image with presence of spherocytes and reticulocytosis. Based on the child’s clinical features and the findings on the peripheral smear, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hereditary spherocytosis

 

Option B:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis is a condition characterized by the presence of spherocytes in the blood smear, which are red blood cells that are more spherical than normal and lack the typical central pallor. This condition leads to hemolysis, which can cause jaundice and an enlarged spleen due to the accumulation of bilirubin. The increased number of reticulocytes represents the bone marrow’s compensatory response to the destruction of spherocytes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sickle cell anemia: This is usually characterized by the presence of sickle-shaped red blood cells, which are not noted in the provided peripheral smear image.

 

Option C. G6PD deficiency: This condition typically presents with episodic hemolysis triggered by certain drugs or foods, and blood smears might show 'bite cells', not the spherocytes as shown.

 

Option D. Thalassemia: It commonly presents with microcytic and hypochromic red cells and target cells, which differ from the spherocytes seen in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis is recognized by the classic triad of jaundice, splenomegaly, and the presence of spherocytes on a peripheral blood smear. The increased reticulocyte count further supports the diagnosis by indicating an increased red blood cell turnover.

 

Ref; Nelson 20th Edition Page no- From 2311.

choices.text: Autosomal recessive is the most common type of inheritance
May be diagnosed by incubated osmotic fragility test
Can be diagnosed by flow cytometry
Presence of Spherocytes in PS has a differential diagnosis of AIHA.

questions.text: A child is brought to the clinic with a familial history of anemia. On examination, the healthcare provider notes the presence of spherocytes in the blood smear. Further genetic analysis reveals a defect in the ankyrin protein of the red blood cells. With this information, a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis is confirmed. Regarding hereditary spherocytosis, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal recessive is the most common type of inheritance

 

Option A:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, not autosomal recessive. The majority of cases are due to mutations that affect proteins involved in the red blood cell cytoskeleton, such as ankyrin, which leads to the characteristic spherocytes seen on blood smear.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. May be diagnosed by incubated osmotic fragility test: True, this test can demonstrate increased fragility of red blood cells in a hypotonic solution, a hallmark of hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Can be diagnosed by flow cytometry: True, flow cytometry can be used to diagnose hereditary spherocytosis by detecting deficiencies in membrane proteins.

 

Option D. Presence of Spherocytes in PS has a differential diagnosis of AIHA: True, while spherocytes are characteristic of hereditary spherocytosis, they can also be seen in autoimmune hemolyticanemia, making it a part of the differential diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis, typically inherited as an autosomal dominant fashion and can be diagnosed with osmotic fragility tests or flow cytometry. Spherocytes on a peripheral smear can indicate hereditary spherocytosis but also need to be differentiated from autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

 

Hereditary Spherocytosis- Ankyrin mutation (M/C-70% cases)- AD

 

Herdeitary Spherocytosis- Spectrin mutation (Most severe)- AR

 

Ref; OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 337.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic with sudden onset pallor and dark urine. The child also exhibits jaundice and pallor on physical examination. The mother mentions that the child recently consumed fava beans, which they had not eaten before. Laboratory results, including a peripheral blood smear, as shown in the image. Based on the child's clinical presentation, history of recent dietary change, and the peripheral smear findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G6PD deficiency

 

Option C:

 

The peripheral smear reveals bite cells/ blister cells and Heinz bodies,which result from the removal of denatured hemoglobin by the spleen.

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency often presents with episodes of acute hemolytic anemia triggered by certain foods, medications, or infections. The consumption of fava beans can precipitate this hemolysis in individuals with G6PD deficiency, a phenomenon known as favism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sickle cell anemia: This condition usually presents with sickle-shaped cells on the smear, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Option B. Hereditary spherocytosis: Characterized by spherocytes on blood smear, hereditary spherocytosis is not typically triggered by dietary factors.

 

Option D. Thalassemia: This genetic condition causes chronic hemolyticanemia with microcytic and hypochromic cells and target cells, but acute episodes are not usually precipitated by food intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency presents as hemolytic anemia precipitated by fava bean consumption, and diagnosed by the characteristic 'bite cells' on a peripheral blood smear.

 

Ref; OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 338

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to a clinic in a malaria-prevalent region with symptoms of fever, chills, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Given the local endemic conditions, a rapid antigen test for malaria is conducted, and the result necessitates the initiation of primaquine treatment. Four days into the therapy, the patient develops hematuria, and laboratory tests reveal a significant drop in hemoglobin levels from 11.3 g/dL to 7.12 g/dL, an increase in total bilirubin from 1.38 mg/dL to 4.52 mg/dL, and an elevation in lactic dehydrogenase (LDH) from 236 IU/L to 509 IU/L. Based on the clinical presentation and the onset of symptoms following primaquine administration, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency

 

Option C:

 

The patient is most probably suffering from G6PD deficiency. The hemolysis is primaquine induced which is an oxidant drug. The rise in bilirubin is due to hemolytic jaundice and The rise in lactic dehydrogenase (LDH) is commonly observed in hemolyticanemias.

 

X-linked Recessive

 

Clinical features:

 

Asymptomatic until their RBC are exposed to certain chemicals in food or medicine, or to stress.

 

  • Dark urine
  • Enlarged spleen
  • Fatigue
  • Pallor
  • Rapid heart rate
  • Shortness of breath
  • Jaundice.

 

Diagnosis: Bite cells on PS.

 

Screening: Qualitative assessment of G6PD enzymatic activity (UV-based test)

 

Confirmatory test: Quantitative measurement of G6PD enzymatic activity

 

Molecular test: Detection of G6PD gene mutation

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC): PDC deficiency affects the mitochondrial conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, leading to neurological symptoms and lactic acidosis, not hemolyticanemia.

 

Option B: Pyruvate kinase deficiency: This is another cause of hemolyticanemia but is less likely to be triggered specifically by primaquine treatment.

 

Option D: Glucose-6-Phosphatase deficiency: This deficiency is associated with glycogen storage disease type I (Von Gierke disease), which presents with hypoglycemia and metabolic abnormalities, not primaquine-induced hemolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency, particularly hemolytic anemia triggered by oxidative stressors such as primaquine in patients with malaria.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 490 – Page  No 10068-10069

questions.text: Manthra, a 13-year-old, is rushed to the emergency department by her mother due to recurrent episodes of nosebleeds (epistaxis), blood in urine (hematuria), and blood in stools (hematochezia). The mother also recalls significant bleeding from the umbilical stump shortly after Manthra's birth. A comprehensive blood panel reveals normal platelet counts and coagulation times, including Prothrombin Time (PT), Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (APTT), Thrombin Time (TT), and fibrinogen levels. However, a urea clot lysis test indicated positive results. Considering these findings, which clotting factor deficiency is most likely present in Manthra?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XIII

 

Option D:

 

Factor XIII (Fibrin Stabilizing Factor) deficiency is the most likely cause of Manthra's symptoms. This condition leads to normal initial clot formation, as evidenced by normal PT, APTT, TT, and fibrinogen levels. However, due to the absence or malfunction of Factor XIII, the clot is unstable and prone to premature lysis, as indicated by a positive urea clot lysis test. Factor XIII is crucial for cross-linking fibrin and stabilizing blood clots. Its deficiency can lead to delayed bleeding episodes, such as umbilical stump bleeding, hematuria, hematochezia, and epistaxis, despite normal initial coagulation tests.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Factor IX: Deficiency leads to Hemophilia B, which would typically result in prolonged APTT.

 

Option B: Factor X: Deficiency would affect both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, leading to abnormalities in PT and APTT.

 

Option C: Factor VIII: Deficiency causes Hemophilia A, also typically presenting with prolonged APTT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XIII deficiencies clinically characterized by normal initial clot formation tests but abnormal clot stability, leading to recurrent and delayed bleeding episodes. The urea clot lysis test can help diagnose this condition by demonstrating the clot's inability to resist lysis, indicating a deficiency in fibrin stabilization.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition. Page No-10225.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their mother due to fever, swelling, and pain in the leg, particularly with movement. Physical examination reveals signs of inflammation, and a complete blood count (CBC) indicates increased neutrophil levels and microcytic anemia. Suspecting osteomyelitis, further inquiries are made into the child's medical history. The mother mentions a familial history of anemia, which, upon further testing, is attributed to a missense mutation at the beta globin's 6th position - a hallmark of sickle cell anemia. Considering the specific type of anemia diagnosed due to this genetic mutation, which organism is most commonly associated with osteomyelitis in such cases?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Salmonella

 

Option D:

 

Based on the history it is a case of Sickle cell anemia, the organism responsible for osteomyelitis in SCA is Salmonella.

 

Organisms responsible for osteomyelitis are:

 

  1. In general population- Staphylococcus aureus
  2. In sickle cell patients- Salmonella is the M/C cause.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Streptococcus pyogenes: While it can cause various infections, it is less commonly associated with osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia.

 

Option B: Staphylococcus aureus: Although it is a common cause of osteomyelitis, in patients with sickle cell anemia, Salmonella species are more prevalent.

 

Option C: Pseudomonas: This organism is more commonly associated with osteomyelitis in individuals with specific risk factors such as intravenous drug use or puncture wounds, not specifically with sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patients with sickle cell anemia, characterized by a missense mutation at the beta globin's 6th position, have an increased risk of developing osteomyelitis due to Salmonella species, differentiating it from the more common causative agent, Staphylococcus aureus, in the general population.

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 6044

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 3-year-old child to the pediatric department due to recurrent infections and noticeable dilated veins over the chest. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes pallor, petechial hemorrhages, and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and a white blood cell count of less than 50,000/cu.mm. These findings lead to a suspicion of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). To confirm the diagnosis of ALL, what key feature would the pediatrician expect to find in the bone marrow aspirate of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) >25%lymphoblasts

 

Option B:

 

ALL (acute lymphoblastic leukemia)-Mc type of leukemia in children and overall mc malignancy in children.

 

Clinical features:

 

  1. Bone pain
  2. Decrease in cell count leading to anemia, thrombocytopenia and leukopenia.
  3. Lymphadenopathy in medaistinal area compress the SVC causing congestion in face and dilated veins over chest.

 

Diagnosis to confirm ALL: Bone marrow aspirate->25% lymphoblast.

 

Note - Myeloblasts are associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), not ALL. While a higher percentage of myeloblasts is indicative of AML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) is confirmed by the presence of a high percentage of lymphoblasts in the bone marrow aspirate. Specifically, the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria for the diagnosis of ALL include the presence of more than 25% lymphoblasts in the bone marrow. This high percentage of immature lymphoid cells is indicative of ALL, distinguishing it from other hematological disorders.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-161, Page No-4830

questions.text: A 6-year-old child from Africa is brought by his parents for medical consultation, presenting with pronounced jaw swelling and ulceration as evident in the provided image. The child also exhibits difficulty breathing due to partial airway obstruction. A biopsy is performed, and histopathological analysis confirms a diagnosis of B-cell Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL). Based on the clinical presentation and biopsy findings, what is the most likely diagnosis, and which chromosomal translocation is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Burkitt’s lymphoma t (8;14)

 

Option D:

 

Burkitt’s lymphoma

  • Caused by the deregulation of the MYC gene on chromosome
  • EBV infection predisposes to c-myc translocation t(8;14)

 

Clinical features; BL is a rapidly growing tumor.

  • The endemic (African) form usually presents as a jaw or facial bone, loosening of teeth, tumor that spreads to extra nodal sites including the mesentery, ovary, testis, kidney, breast, and especially to the bone marrow and meninges

 

INVESTIGATION

  • CBC
  • RFTs and Serum electrolytes, uric acid, creatinine, calcium, phosphorus, Biopsy - histological Dx

 

Histology —

  • Cytologically, BL cells resemble the small non-cleaved cells within normal germinal centers
  • A "starry sky" pattern is usually present
     

Management

  • General management Prevent tumour lysis SDM
  • Rehydrate the patient
  • Allopurinol and Rasburicase.
  • Specific management; Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Prednisolone (CHOP)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt’s lymphoma, especially the classic presentation is of jaw swelling in African children, and its associated with the chromosomal translocation t(8;14).

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 6904

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy in India is brought to the hospital with a history of recurrent bacterial infections, including otitis media, sinusitis, and pneumonia. He has no significant family history of immunodeficiency disorders. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild otitis media. Laboratory tests reveal markedly low levels of IgG, IgA, and IgM. Which condition is most likely to be diagnosed based on the clinical features and investigation findings in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (XLA)

 

Option C:

 

X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (XLA) is a condition characterized by a significant reduction in all types of immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, and IgM) due to a lack of B cells, leading to recurrent bacterial infections from an early age. The clinical presentation of recurrent otitis media, sinusitis, and pneumonia, combined with markedly low levels of immunoglobulins, strongly suggests XLA. This condition typically presents in male children between the ages of 6 months and 5 years, after maternal IgG levels decline.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID): CVID can present with similar symptoms but usually has a later onset, and patients may have some immunoglobulins present, albeit at reduced levels.

 

Option B. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID): SCID is characterized by a profound deficiency of T- and B-cell function, leading to severe infections early in life, often within the first few months. The child's age and the type of infections described make SCID less likely.

 

Option D. Hyper-IgM Syndrome: This condition involves normal or elevated levels of IgM with low levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE, which does not match the laboratory findings in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (XLA), a primary immunodeficiency disorder, should be suspected in male children presenting with recurrent bacterial infections, particularly otitis media, sinusitis, and pneumonia, combined with significantly low levels of immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, and IgM).

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition. page 4627

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who is concerned about the child's history of recurrent, severe infections including pneumonia, oral thrush, and a past episode of sepsis. Laboratory tests reveal markedly low levels of T cells and absent or low B cells. Which condition is the most likely diagnosis for this infant based on the clinical history and laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

 

Option B:

 

The presence of recurrent severe infections such as pneumonia, thrush, and sepsis, along with laboratory findings showing low levels of T cells and absent or low B cells, is indicative of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID). SCID is a primary immunodeficiency characterized by the defective function and/or absence of both T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes, leading to severe infections early in life.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID): CVID typically presents later in childhood or adolescence with hypogammaglobulinemia and normal T-cell numbers.

 

C. X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (XLA): XLA typically presents with low or absent B cells and normal T-cell counts, not the T-cell deficiency observed here.

 

Option D. Hyper-IgM syndrome: Characterized by high levels of IgM with low levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE, and typically normal T-cell counts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCID is characterized by a lack of T cells, B cells, and natural killer cells, leading to severe, life-threatening infections in infancy. Early diagnosis is crucial for the management and survival of these infants, with interventions such as bone marrow transplant offering potentially curative treatment.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No- 1022-1024.

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-year-old boy Raju with complaints of recurrent bacterial infections, including otitis media and pneumonia. Laboratory evaluations show markedly low levels of immunoglobulins across all classes and an absence of mature B cells. Given Raju's clinical presentation and lab results, which condition is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (XLA)

 

Option C:

 

X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (XLA) is characterized by very low levels of immunoglobulins due to a lack of mature B cells. This condition is typically caused by a mutation in the Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene, which is crucial for B cell development. Patients with XLA present with recurrent bacterial infections early in life.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID): This condition usually presents later in childhood or in adulthood and involves low levels of immunoglobulins but not a complete absence of B cells.

 

Option B. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID): While SCID also leads to recurrent infections and can involve low levels of B cells, it is more severe and involves T cells as well.

 

Option D. Hyper-IgM syndrome: This condition involves high levels of IgM with low levels of other immunoglobulins, which is not consistent with Raju's lab findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (XLA) is a rare primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a lack of mature B cells and very low levels of immunoglobulins. XLA typically presents in early childhood with recurrent bacterial infections, such as otitis media and pneumonia.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No- 4629.

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-week-old son to the clinic, concerned that his umbilical cord has not yet detached. The infant, born at term, appears active and well, with no signs of illness or fever. Examination reveals the intact umbilical cord and a shallow, 0.5 cm ulceration at the occiput without discharge or erythema, which has been slowly healing since birth. Given this presentation, which finding is most likely associated with the child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Marked neutrophilia

 

Option D:

 

Delayed umbilical cord detachment and poor wound healing, as seen in this child, can be indicative of Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD), a rare immunodeficiency disorder. LAD is characterized by a defect in leukocyte adherence glycoproteins, leading to impaired migration of white blood cells to sites of infection or injury, resulting in marked neutrophilia due to the inability of neutrophils to exit the bloodstream.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Defective humoral response: This would suggest a problem with B cells or antibodies, which is not directly indicated by the delayed umbilical cord detachment or the slow-healing ulcer.

 

Option B. Functional leukocyte adherence glycoproteins: This option is contrary to what is expected in LAD, where these glycoproteins are dysfunctional.

 

Option C. Normal wound healing: The slow-healing ulcer at the occiput contradicts normal wound healing processes, suggesting an underlying issue like LAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD).

 

  • LAD is an inheritable disorder of leukocyte chemotaxis and adherence characterized by recurring sinopulmonary, oropharyngeal, and cutaneous infections with delayed wound healing.
  • Neutrophilia is common with WBC counts of typically more than 50,000 cells/mm3.
  • Severe, life-threatening infection is possible with Staphylococcus species, Enterobacteriaceae, and Candida species.
  • Good skin and oral hygiene are important; broad-spectrum antimicrobials and surgical debridement are early considerations with infection.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No- 999-1001.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old son Raja to the clinic, concerned about his recurrent infections, eczema, and episodes of thrombocytopenia. Physical examination reveals small, circular, scaly patches on the skin. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the WASP gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS)

 

Option D:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is a rare X-linked recessive disease characterized by the triad of eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia (small platelets). The WASP gene mutation affects the ability of immune cells to respond to pathogens correctly and impacts platelet formation, leading to the symptoms observed in Raja.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atopic dermatitis: While eczema is common in atopic dermatitis, it does not typically present with recurrent infections or thrombocytopenia associated with WASP gene mutations.

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is an autoimmune blistering disorder that does not typically present with recurrent infections or thrombocytopenia and has no connection to WASP gene mutations.

 

Option C. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia: This type of leukemia occurs mostly in adults and is characterized by the accumulation of functionally incompetent lymphocytes, not typically associated with WASP gene mutations or the triad of symptoms seen in WAS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WAS is a rare X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder characterized by eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia. It is associated with WASP gene mutation.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition. Page No-1027.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, night sweats, and lethargy. Physical examination reveals a few firm, rubbery lymph nodes. A lymph node biopsy shows the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, and subsequent PET CT identifies the involvement of four additional lymph nodes on the same side of the diaphragm as shown in the image. Suspecting Hodgkin's lymphoma, you proceed to stage the disease for treatment planning. Based on the information and evaluation provided, what is the stage of the lymphoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage 2

 

Option B:

 

HODGKINS LYMPHOMA:

 

It has bimodal distribution -15-19 and 5th -6th decade.

 

Clinical features:

  • Lymphadenopathy: lymph node-firm, rubbery.
  • Symptoms: unexplained fever, weight loss over 6 months (significant weight loss)  and drenching night sweats.
  • Lethargy, anorexia, pruritis (less common).

 

Diagnosis:Excisional biopsy.

 

HPE: Classical reed steen berg cell (owl eye inclusion body)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Stage 1: This stage is characterized by the involvement of a single lymph node region, which does not match the patient's findings.

 

Option C: Stage 3: Involvement on both sides of the diaphragm or additional extralymphatic organ involvement, which is not indicated here.

 

Option D: Stage 4: Diffuse or disseminated involvement of one or more extralymphatic organs, which is not indicated in the provided clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on PET CT staging is done.

 

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-161, Page No-4835-4840.

questions.text: A mother is concerned about her 3-year-old son, who has had hearing loss, cataracts, and heart defects since birth. During a clinic visit, the child presents with a low-grade fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy. Considering the combination of congenital conditions and current symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rubella

Option B:

The child's presentation of congenital hearing loss, cataracts, and heart defects is indicative of Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS), which occurs when a fetus is infected with the rubella virus in utero. The additional findings of low-grade fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy in the child could also be related to an acute rubella infection or a reactivation, although reactivation is extremely rare. Rubella is known for its mild symptoms compared to other viral exanthems but can have severe teratogenic effects if infection occurs during pregnancy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Mumps: Primarily affects the salivary glands and can lead to complications such as orchitis, meningitis, and pancreatitis, but it is not associated with the congenital anomalies described.

 

Option C: Measles (Rubeola): Characterized by a high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a rash that starts on the face and spreads downwards. It does not cause the congenital defects mentioned.

 

Option D: Chickenpox (Varicella): Presents with an itchy rash that turns into fluid-filled blisters and eventually crusts over, but is not known to cause congenital heart defects, cataracts, and hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hearing loss, cataracts, and heart defects, are classic findings in Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS).

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No- 1579-1585.

questions.text: A new mother is concerned about her 1-week-old infant who has been experiencing fever, poor feeding, and a vesicular rash on the face and trunk. She reveals that she had a similar rash during her pregnancy and at the time of delivery. The Tzanck smear of the lesion is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation of the infant and the mother's history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Infection   

 

Option C:

 

  • Tzanck smear shows Acantholytic cells, multinucleated giant cells and eosinophilic inclusion bodies in HSV infection.
  • HSV is a common viral infection that can be transmitted from a mother to her foetus during pregnancy or delivery.
  • Infants with congenital HSV infection may present with fever, poor feeding, and vesicular rash on the face and trunk.
  • The mother's history of genital herpes during pregnancy is a strong risk factor for the diagnosis of congenital HSV infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Congenital Rubella Syndrome: Typically presents with cataracts, heart defects, and hearing loss, and not with the vesicular rash seen in herpes infections.

 

Option B: Congenital Cytomegalovirus Infection: Can cause a variety of symptoms, including hearing loss, microcephaly, and hepatosplenomegaly. While CMV can cause a petechial rash known as "blueberry muffin" spots, it does not cause the vesicular rash seen in herpes infections.

 

Option D: Congenital Toxoplasmosis: Often presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications, and does not present with vesicular rash characteristic of herpes infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Tzanck smear image showing multinucleated giant cells is indicative of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. The presence of a vesicular rash in both the mother during pregnancy and the newborn, alongside the mother's history and the Tzanck smear findings, strongly suggests congenital herpes simplex virus infection. HSV can be transmitted to the infant during delivery if the mother has active genital lesions, leading to neonatal herpes, which can present with fever, poor feeding, and vesicular rash.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, page no 13283

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visits a clinic in an urban area of Mumbai, India, with a distinctive rash that initiated on her face before spreading to her trunk and limbs. She describes experiencing a low-grade fever and notes palpable lymph node enlargement in her cervical region. During the oropharyngeal examination, the healthcare provider observes small, rose-colored lesions on the palate. Considering the clinical presentation and potential future complications discussed, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rubella

 

Option B:

 

Rubella, also known as German measles, typically presents with a mild rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities, low-grade fever, and lymphadenopathy. Forchheimer spots (tiny, rose-coloured lesions in oropharynx) are also characteristic of rubella. The mention of a risk of panencephalitis in the future aligns with rubella, as one of its rare long-term complications is progressive rubella panencephalitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Measles: Measles can present with a rash, but the rash typically starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities. Measles rash is typically accompanied by high fever, cough, and conjunctivitis.

 

Option C: Chickenpox: Chickenpox can present with a rash, but the rash typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and extremities. Chickenpox rash is typically accompanied by itching and fever.


Option D: Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever can present with a rash, but the rash typically presents as a fine, sandpaper-like rash that starts on the trunk and spreads to the extremities. The rash is typically accompanied by a strawberry tongue and peeling of the skin. Scarlet fever rash does not typically start on the face.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical manifestations of rubella, includes facial rash spreading to the trunk and extremities, low-grade fever, lymphadenopathy, and Forchheimer spots, and rare long-term neurological complications like progressive rubella panencephalitis.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1548-1551.

choices.text: Acellular bone marrow with reduction of all cell lines
Erythroid hyperplasia as a result of JAK-2 mutation.
Reduced erythropoiesis with giant erythroblasts and intranuclear inclusions
“Owl eye” appearance, due to CMV infection in erythroid precursors

questions.text: Vijay, a 5-year-old boy from a village near Chennai, is brought to the pediatric department of a District Hospital. His medical history is notable for hereditary spherocytosis. The mother reports that Vijay has been looking increasingly pale and lethargic. The exacerbation of anemia is suspected, and upon examination, a significant decrease in reticulocyte counts is observed, suggesting an inadequate response to anemia. Given these clinical findings, a bone marrow examination is performed. What findings are most likely to be observed in Vijay's bone marrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acellular bone marrow with reduction of all cell lines

 

Explanation:

 

In a patient with hereditary spherocytosis who presents with an exacerbation of anemia and decreased reticulocyte counts, the findings are suggestive of an aplastic crisis with human parvovirus B19. This condition is characterized by a temporary cessation of red blood cell production, resulting in an acellular bone marrow with a reduction in all cell lines.

 

Patients usually recover in 4-6 weeks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Erythroid hyperplasia as a result of JAK-2 mutation: JAK-2 mutations are typically associated with myeloproliferative disorders, not hereditary spherocytosis, and would not result in decreased reticulocyte counts.

 

Option C. Reduced erythropoiesis with giant erythroblasts and intranuclear inclusions: These findings are indicative of disorders such as megaloblastic anemia, not hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option D. “Owl eye” appearance, due to CMV infection in erythroid precursors: This finding is associated with CMV infection, not hereditary spherocytosis, and would not account for the sudden decrease in reticulocytes typical of an aplastic crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presentation of an aplastic crisis in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis, characterized by acute worsening of anemia and low reticulocyte counts. Bone marrow biopsy would typically show an acellular marrow with reduction of all cell lines. Understanding this complication is crucial for the appropriate management of patients with hereditary hemolyticanemias.

 

Ref; OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No-337.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy with diagnosed Down syndrome, characterized by intellectual disability, a mongoloid slant of the eyes, and sandal gap toes, is brought in by his parents for evaluation. The parents, who had not sought further medical advice post-prenatal diagnosis due to the child's gender, express concerns about the risk of leukemia, specifically asking about Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). Addressing their concerns, you also consider the association of Down syndrome with myeloid leukemias. You then turn to your junior with a teaching question, "What is the most common leukemia of myeloid lineage seen in children with Down syndrome?"
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia(M7).

 

Option A:

 

Children with Down syndrome have an increased risk of developing certain types of leukemia, with Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia (AMKL) being the most common myeloid leukemia in this population. While children with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) are at a higher risk for ALL, when considering myeloid lineage leukemias specifically, AMKL is more prevalent. This form of leukemia is characterized by the proliferation of megakaryoblasts, an early form of cells that eventually develop into platelets.

 

Note - The most common leukemia in case of down syndrome is ALL , but most common myeloid origin leukemia is Acute megakaryoblasticleukemia, which is AML M7.

 

FAB classification (for Leukemia’s)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Acute erythroid leukemia: This is a rare form of acute myeloid leukemia characterized by the proliferation of erythroid precursors, not specifically associated with Down syndrome.

 

Option C: Acute myelomonocytic leukemia: While this is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia, it is not the most common in children with Down syndrome.

 

Option D: Acute monocytic leukemia: This leukemia subtype involves the proliferation of monocytes and is not the most common myeloid leukemia in children with Down syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The increased risk of leukemia in children with Down syndrome, with a specific focus on Acute MegakaryoblasticLeukemia (AMKL) as the most common myeloid lineage leukemia in this population. Recognizing the association between genetic syndromes and specific types of leukemia can aid in the early diagnosis and management of these conditions.

 

Ref; Nelson 20th Edition , Page  No 610-615 and Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-161, Page No-4832.

questions.text: A worried mother came to pediatric department along with her 3-year-old kid with complaints of recurrent infection and dilated veins over the chest. During physical examination of the child, pallor, petechial hemorrhage and hepatosplenomegaly were found. Peripheral blood findings show the presence of anemia, thrombocytopenia and WBC <50,000/cu.mm. You suspect it as a case of ALL. What will you find in the bone marrow aspirate of this child to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. >25%lymphoblasts

 

ALL (acute lymphoblastic leukemia)-Mc type of leukemia in children and overall mc malignancy in children.

 

Clinical features:

  1. Bone pain
  2. Decrease in cell count leading to anemia, thrombocytopenia and leukopenia.
  3. Lymphadenopathy in medaistinal area compress the SVC causing congestion in face and dilated veins over chest.

Diagnosis to confirm ALL: Bone marrow aspirate->25% lymphoblast.

 

Option C :is diagnostic for AML.

 

Option B and D has no significance on ALL.

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-161, Page No-4830

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to a government hospital in rural Odisha, India, with a 3-day history of high fever peaking at 39°C, associated with chills, headache, and episodes of vomiting. The mother reports that the child was previously healthy and has no significant medical history. Physical examination reveals pallor and an enlarged spleen. Laboratory investigations including a complete blood count confirm anaemia. A peripheral blood smear is positive for Plasmodium falciparum parasites. Given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, what is the most appropriate treatment option for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy

 

Option A:

 

Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy: (ACT)

 

This is the current recommended first-line treatment for severe malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum, particularly in children. It has been shown to be more effective than intravenous quinine and is associated with fewer side effects. It acts quickly to reduce parasite load and fever, making it a critical treatment option in severe cases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Chloroquine tablets: While chloroquine was once widely used to treat malaria, it is no longer effective against Plasmodium falciparum due to the development of widespread resistance. As such, it is not a recommended treatment option for this case.

 

Option C: Primaquine tablets: Primaquine is typically used as a second-line treatment for malaria, particularly to target the hypnozoite stage of the parasite in the liver. However, it is not effective against Plasmodium falciparum, which is the parasite causing the current case. Therefore, it is not an appropriate treatment option in this case.

 

Option D: Symptomatic management. As this is a case of severe malaria, Symptomatic management can’t be used as a treatment modality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treat Plasmodium falciparum malaria with the appropriate first-line therapy, which is Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT), particularly in regions with chloroquine resistance. Recognize that specific anti-malarial treatment is necessary alongside supportive care in managing acute malaria.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1712-1719.

choices.text: High dose methotrexate and high dose cytarabine
Low dose methotrexate and high dose cytarabine

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy who has completed treatment for Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) is brought in for a follow-up visit six months post-therapy. Despite completing the treatment regimen, his bone marrow aspirate reveals a concerning 35% presence of lymphoblasts. Given this finding, which indicates a relapse of the disease, what would be the next appropriate step in managing this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High dose methotrexate and high dose cytarabine

 

Option A:

For a relapsed ALL, the typical approach includes more intensive chemotherapy regimens to try and achieve a second remission. High-dose methotrexate and high-dose cytarabine are used together as part of such a reinduction chemotherapy protocol, which can be effective in treating recurrent disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Low-dose methotrexate only: This would be insufficient for treating relapsed ALL, as it typically requires a more aggressive treatment regimen.

 

Option C: High-dose methotrexate only: While high-dose methotrexate is a component of reinduction therapy, it is usually combined with other chemotherapeutic agents for greater efficacy in the case of relapse.

 

Option D: Low-dose methotrexate and high-dose cytarabine: Low-dose methotrexate alone is not adequate for relapsed ALL and is not typically combined with high-dose cytarabine for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of relapsed Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia in a pediatric patient - A combination of high-dose methotrexate and high-dose cytarabine is part of the standard reinduction therapy to achieve a second remission in patients with relapsed ALL.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-161, Page No-4830

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl named Mala is brought to the pediatrician by her mother due to a decrease in school performance linked to frequent infections. Mala has a history of recurrent sinusitis and bacterial pneumonia. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of IgM with low levels of other immunoglobulin isotypes. Based on these clinical and laboratory findings, which condition is most likely affecting this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hyper-IgM syndrome

 

Option D:

 

Hyper-IgM syndrome is characterized by normal or elevated levels of IgM with low levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE. This condition is due to a defect in the CD40 ligand on T cells, which is necessary for class switching in B cells. Patients typically present with recurrent sinopulmonary infections due to the lack of IgG, which is crucial for opsonization and protection against encapsulated bacteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID): Typically presents with low levels of IgG and IgA and normal or only slightly elevated levels of IgM, not the high IgM levels seen in this case.

 

Option B. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID): This condition usually presents in infancy with severe, life-threatening infections and involves a combined deficiency of both B and T cells, which is more severe than the symptoms presented by Mala.

 

Option C. X-linked Agammaglobulinemia (XLA): Characterized by very low or absent B cells and all immunoglobulin isotypes, except for IgM, which may be normal or low but not elevated as in Hyper-IgM syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper-IgM syndrome is characterized by elevated levels of IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulin isotypes, leading to recurrent bacterial infections, particularly involving the sinuses, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition.page 5462

questions.text: An 8-month-old girl is brought in by her mother due to decreased fluid intake, vomiting, and watery diarrhea over the past 3 days. The father mentions the child's persistent thrush since birth, despite treatment, and two hospitalizations for pneumonia in the last four months. The child's weight has significantly dropped from the 50th to the 5th percentile. Physical examination reveals buccal mucosal exudates and hyperactive bowel sounds, but no dehydration signs, although extremity muscle wasting is noted. Given these findings and the history, severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is suspected. Which of the following findings is consistent with SCID?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Defective cellular immunity

 

Option C:

 

SCID is an autosomal recessive or X-linked disorder of both humoral and cellular immunity. Serum immunoglobulins and T cells are often markedly diminished or absent. Thymic dysgenesis is also seen. Recurring cutaneous, gastrointestinal, or pulmonary infections occur with opportunistic organisms such as cytomegalovirus (CMV) and PCP.

 

Death typically occurs in the first 12 to 24 months of life unless bone marrow transplantation is performed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), characterized by recurrent severe infections, failure to thrive, and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, and understand that defective cellular immunity is a key feature of the disease.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No- 1022-1024.

questions.text: A mother is concerned about her 3-week-old infant who is presenting with a rash, nasal discharge, and swollen lymph nodes. Upon further inquiry, the mother reveals she had a painless ulcer with a firm base during her pregnancy. The diagnosis was confirmed through darkfield microscopy. Based on the infant's clinical presentation and the mother's history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital Syphilis

 

Option C:

 

  • Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium (spirochete) Treponema pallidum.
  • Congenital syphilis occurs when the infection is transmitted from an infected mother to her developing foetus during pregnancy.
  • Infants with congenital syphilis may present with a range of symptoms, including rash, swollen lymph nodes, nasal discharge, and bone abnormalities.
  • The mother's history of syphilis during pregnancy is a strong risk factor for the diagnosis of congenital syphilis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Congenital Rubella Syndrome: Typically presents with cataracts, heart defects, and hearing loss. The mother's symptoms and the diagnostic method do not align with rubella.

 

Option B: Congenital Cytomegalovirus Infection: Can lead to a variety of symptoms including hearing loss, microcephaly, and hepatosplenomegaly, but the mother's specific symptom and darkfield microscopy are not indicative of CMV.

 

Option D: Congenital Toxoplasmosis: Often presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. The mother's symptom and the diagnostic method used do not suggest toxoplasmosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chancre is a hallmark of primary syphilis in the mother, and the use of darkfield microscopy to visualize Treponema pallidum (the causative agent of syphilis) is a classic diagnostic technique. Congenital syphilis can manifest in newborns as rash, nasal discharge (snuffles), and lymphadenopathy, among other symptoms.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1470-1477.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department of a tertiary care hospital in New Delhi, India, with a chief complaint of dark-colored urine and noticeable yellowing of the skin. The child's parents also report that the child tires easily. Upon clinical examination, the healthcare provider observes clear signs of jaundice. To further investigate, a complete blood count (CBC) and a peripheral blood smear are ordered. The blood smear results show the presence of schistocytes (fragmented red cells) and an increased number of reticulocytes (immature red blood cells), indicative of active red blood cell production. Given the combination of clinical symptoms and laboratory findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemolyticanemia

 

Option B:

 

Hemolyticanemia is characterized by the premature destruction of red blood cells, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, dark urine (due to the presence of bilirubin), and jaundice. The presence of schistocytes on the blood smear is indicative of red cell fragmentation, a hallmark of intravascular hemolysis, while an increased reticulocyte count suggests the bone marrow is responding to anemia by producing more red blood cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: This is the most common type of anemia globally, often presenting with microcytic hypochromic anemia, but it does not typically lead to hemolysis, schistocytes, or an elevated reticulocyte count.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: While sickle cell anemia is a form of hemolyticanemia, it has distinct clinical and laboratory findings, such as sickle-shaped red blood cells on the smear, which were not mentioned in this case.

 

Option D. Thalassemia: Thalassemia can cause hemolyticanemia but is characterized by specific morphological changes in red blood cells such as target cells and microcytosis, and the presence of schistocytes is not typical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical and laboratory features of hemolyticanemia, including symptoms like dark urine and jaundice, along with laboratory findings such as schistocytes and elevated reticulocyte counts, which differentiate it from other types of anemia such as iron deficiency anemia, sickle cell anemia, and thalassemia.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 339-343

choices.text: G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder
The condition is more common in females than males
Patients may experience hemolysis after exposure to certain medications and infections
Treatment may include avoiding triggers and blood transfusions

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is taken to the pediatrician with complaints of unexplained pallor, fatigue, and shortness of breath. After a detailed clinical evaluation, the peripheral blood smear is examined, revealing the presence of bite cells and Heinz bodies within the red blood cells. Based on these findings, the physician diagnoses the child with Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Regarding G6PD deficiency, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The condition is more common in females than males

 

Option B:

 

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder, meaning it is more common in males than females. Patients may present with hemolysis after exposure to certain triggers, such as medications and infections. Treatment may include avoiding triggers and, in severe cases, blood transfusions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder: True, the G6PD gene is located on the X chromosome, and the deficiency typically manifests in males.

 

Option C. Patients may experience hemolysis after exposure to certain medications and infections: True, individuals with G6PD deficiency may have episodes of hemolysis when exposed to oxidative stress from various triggers.

 

Option D. Treatment may include avoiding triggers and blood transfusions: True, the mainstay of treatment in G6PD deficiency is to avoid known triggers, and blood transfusions may be necessary for severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that affects males more commonly than females, can lead to hemolytic anemia upon exposure to certain triggers, and is managed by avoiding these triggers and, in some cases, with blood transfusions.

 

Ref; OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 338

choices.text: Pentamers of excess beta globin chains
Pentamers of excess alpha globin chains
Tetramers of excess gamma globin chains

questions.text: A mother with a noted history of polyhydramnios during pregnancy is brought in with the onset of labor pains. Upon delivery, the newborn is observed to have a notably large abdomen characterized by hepatosplenomegaly and ascites, in addition to skin edema. These clinical findings lead to a diagnosis of hydrops fetalis. Regarding hydrops fetalis, particularly in the context of hemoglobinopathies, which of the following statements is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tetramers of excess gamma globin chains

 

Option D:

 

Hydrops Fetalis is the most severe form of alpha-thalassemia which is a result of deletion of all four alpha-globin genes.

 

  • In the fetus, excess gamma-globin chains form tetramers (hemoglobin Barts) with such a high affinity for oxygen that they deliver almost no oxygen to tissues, Which can results in death of the child.
  • Hemoglobin H Disease is caused by deletion of three alpha-globin genes with only one normal alpha-globin gene, the synthesis of a chain is markedly reduced and tetramers of excess beta-globin, called HbH, forms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Deletion of two alpha genes results in alpha-thalassemia trait or minor, which is generally asymptomatic or associated with only mild anemia, not hydrops fetalis.

 

Option B: Pentamers of excess beta globin chains and Option C. Pentamers of excess alpha globin chains are not recognized configurations in hemoglobinopathies related to hydrops fetalis. Hemoglobin in these conditions forms abnormal tetramers, not pentamers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrops fetalis, in the context of hemoglobinopathies, is often due to alpha-thalassemia major, where the deletion of all four alpha-globin genes leads to the formation of tetramers of excess gamma globin chains (Hb Bart's), resulting in ineffective oxygen transport and severe fetal anemia.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition page 3120

questions.text: A newborn diagnosed with Down syndrome presents with pallor and petechiae. Routine blood investigations reveal leukocytosis with the presence of blast cells, and further evaluation in the NICU indicates hepatosplenomegaly. Given these findings in a newborn with Down syndrome, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transient myeloproliferative disorder

 

Option A:

Transient myeloproliferative disorder (TMD) is a condition commonly associated with newborns who have Down syndrome. TMD is characterized by an increased number of blast cells (immature white blood cells), leukocytosis, and often hepatosplenomegaly. While it mimics acute leukemia, specifically acute myeloid leukemia (AML), TMD is typically transient and resolves on its own within a few months, although some cases may progress to AML later in life.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL): While ALL is a common leukemia in children, it's very rare in newborns and is not typically associated with Down syndrome.

 

Option C: Acute myeloproliferative leukemia (AML): Newborns with Down syndrome are at increased risk for AML, but TMD is much more common in the neonatal period and can resemble AML.

 

Option D: None of the above: One of the listed diagnoses is associated with the described presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transient myeloproliferative disorder is characterized by high leukocyte counts, blasts cells in peripheral blood with anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly.

  • Resolves within first 3 months.
  • It has GATA 1 mutation.
  • Require monitoring (20% may develop acute myeloid leukemia by 3 years of age).

 

Ref: Ghai 9th edition – Page no – 600.
